moves.1. d4 d5 2. b3 Nc6 3. Bb2 e6 4. Nf3 f6: I'm a little dubious about this move.  It doesn't seem wise to compromise the Kingside.
moves.5. e3 a6 6. a3 b5 7. Bd3 g5 8. Nfd2: I could have castled instead, but I didn't want my N chased off.  I can always castle Queenside if need be.
moves.8... f5: I was surprised by this.  Black has decided on an all-out assault on the Kingside.  Theoretically, this is a bad idea.  In practice, it was not easy to handle at all.
moves.9. Qh5+ Kd7: Black now cannot castle.  I'm hoping that having the K in the center will make it more difficult to coordinate his pieces.
moves.10. Qe2 g4 11. c4 Ke8: I think Black needed to play bxc5 here.
moves.12. cxb5 axb5 13. Bxb5: Now I've managed to sneak a pawn.
moves.13... Bd7 14. f3: Castling was still probably a better idea.
moves.14... Nf6 15. fxg4 fxg4 16. Bd3: Again, I don't recall why I was paranoid about castling.  As I am annotating the game, I'm not sure how easy it would be for Black to create pressure.
moves.16... Rg8 17. e4: It's important to break in the center, but it might not be the best idea with my K exposed.
moves.17... h5 18. e5 Ne4: This loses another pawn.  Black is staking everything on the Kingside pawn storm succeeding.
moves.19. Nxe4 dxe4 20. Bxe4 Rb8 21. Nd2: It's hard to believe we're 21 moves into the game and my Rs are still not linked.
moves.21... Bh6 22. b4 Bxd2+ 23. Kxd2: It took 23 moves to get developed and I'm still not happy about the exposed position of my K.  In compensation, I have a two pawn material advantage.
moves.23... Ne7 24. Rac1 Bb5 25. Bd3 c6 26. Bx: Exchanging should tend the help the player with the material edge, unless you are trading good pieces for bad ones.
I now control the f file.  It is not as easy for Black to get control of the c file.
moves.29... Qd5 30. Qxd5: Again, exchanges tend to help me.
moves.30... cxd5 31. Rf6 Kd7 32. Rh6 Rb8 33. R: Now I've got a three pawn edge.
moves.33... Rg8 34. a4: You need to attack where you have advantage.  My Queenside pawns are unopposed and mobile.  Away they go!
moves.34... Nc6 35. Rh7+ Kc8 36. b5 Na5 37. Bc: I have to prevent Nc4+ with the B still sitting on b2.
moves.37... Nc4+ 38. Ke2: Moving the K to e2 prevents the R from penetrating on the f file.
moves.38... Rf8 39. a5 Rd8 40. Re7 Rh8 41. Rg7: If Black plays Rxh2, I have Rxg4, getting back the pawn and guarding g2.
moves.42... Nb5 43. Bb2: Now the B dominates the N.  It has nowhere to move.
moves.43... Kb8 44. a6 Rc8 45. a7+: I have to prevent the R from penetrating on the c file, but I have time for a check first.
moves.45... Nxa7 46. bxa7+ Ka8: Now I've got a nice material edge, although it is still not that easy to convert,
moves.47. Kd3: Preventing the R from causing problems.
moves.47... Rc4 48. Ba3: Black sees that after Bc5, my R will be free to pick off more of Black's pawns.  Black's K cannot fight.  Game over.
